events.title: Welcome to the NGI Policy Summit 2020
events.text: Join us for a brief welcome from our partners at the City of Amsterdam and the Ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations of the Netherlands. Together, we'll take a look back at Amsterdam's role in the early days of the internet - and the challenges that lie ahead for all of Europe.

events.title: Visions for the future Internet: what if?
events.text: In this series of short lightning talks, we will hear from speakers about possible—and sometimes quirky—futures for the internet. Join us to share your own thoughts and visions for digital life in 2030.

events.title: Keynote: European Commission
events.text: Join us for the first keynote of the Summit, where we'll hear from the European Commission about their ambitions for the Next Generation Internet.

events.title: The case for a European data economy
events.text: A group discussion setting out a positive vision for Europe’s data economy, looking at data spaces and trusts, the concept of data sovereignty and the European Commission’s key initiatives in this space. We will focus on opportunities for Europe to build more equitable economic models by harnessing innovation, entrepreneurship and standard-setting powers.

events.title: A digital roadmap for 2030: defining Europe’s role after COVID-19
events.text: A scene-setting panel discussion of current and upcoming digital policy proposals from across Europe and MS. This will also serve to map out the road to 2030, looking at some of the big policy problems that will need to be resolved over the coming years, including on the conference’s main topics.

events.title: Decentralising the internet: the 'Blockchains for Social Good' prize
events.text: With the 'Blockchains for Social Good' Prize, the European Innovatoin Council (EIC) recognises and supports the recent efforts of developers and civil society to decentralise and apply blockchains for social innovation. Meet the winners of €5 million award and join us for a brief look at the six challenge areas that our innovators are tackling: traceability and fair trade, financial inclusion, decentralised circular economy, transparency of public processes, participation in democratic decision-making, and management of public records.

events.title: [Workshop] Digital identity
events.text: The Netherlands has recently developed a vision for digital identity that allows for experimentation. In this workshop, presented by officials from the Dutch Ministry of the Interior, participants will learn about this vision and opportunities for international cooperation in the realm of Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI). We will also discuss an international use case in the European Blockchain Partnership.

events.title: [Workshop] Biometrics and facial recognition in cities
events.text: Across the EU, highly intrusive and legally questionable biometric processing technologies, including facial recognition, are quietly becoming ubiquitous in our public and publicly-accessible spaces. In this special session with European Digital Rights (EDRi), a network of 44 civil society digital rights organisations, we will provide an update on the present situation, and together with policy makers from across Europe, discuss different scenarios for the role that biometrics might play in cities in the near future. We will explore whether cities can actually use such technologies in a privacy-friendly way or if they should abolish them altogether. The goal of this session is to involve policy thinkers and decision makers in a productive conversation on privacy in cities.

events.title: [Workshop] Learnings from critical making - Good Things for the Next Generation Internet
events.text:
By connecting products to the internet — by adding a data layer to the physical world, and by physically manifesting the internet — we change the very nature of the things themselves. And for the last decade or two, just about everything has been connected one way or another. At ThingsCon, we’ve been exploring how to do so more responsibly, and…better.

Critical making is a crucial part of the mix of gathering understanding in connected products over the years. ThingsCon has built a reputation to mix critical making with policy thinking and in this session, we like to share learnings from years of involving the makers’ community to foster the creation of a responsible IoT. Making as a way of understanding and grounding, or just as a way to bring home the policy discussions.

events.title: [Workshop] Data-sharing in cities
events.text: Join us for a workshop for city and regional stakeholders that explores the application of digital rights in local data-sharing platforms throughout planning, implementation, and evolution. Looking at case studies from Toronto, Zaragoza, Berlin, Newcastle, Rennes, Bordeaux, and Helsinki, we will discuss how city platforms for data-sharing are created from different building blocks (policies, processes, infrastructures, and actions) to extract value from urban big data.

events.title: [Workshop] AI and public control I: the why and how of accountable AI
events.text: AI offers many benefits for citizens, companies and society as a whole - provided it is designed in a human-centric, ethical and sustainable way, with respect for fundamental rights and values. How can we control this technology,to ensure transparency and fair use? Join us for an expert Q&A, co-hosted by the AINow Institute, Mozilla, Nesta and Ada Lovelace, in which we explore procurement guidelines, registry, and data-ethics decisions.

events.title: [Workshop] AI and public control II: tools for AI accountability
events.text: AI offers many benefits for citizens, companies and society as a whole - provided it is designed in a human-centric, ethical and sustainable way, with respect for fundamental rights and values. How can we control this technology,to ensure transparency and fair use? Join us for an expert Q&A, co-hosted by the AINow Institute, Mozilla, Nesta and Ada Lovelace, in which we explore procurement guidelines, registry, and data-ethics decisions.

events.title: [Workshop] What future internet do we want?
events.text: In this immersive futures workshop, hosted by Nesta Italia, our audience gets to decide on key design principles for the internet, and explores what future scenarios their decisions might yield.

events.title: Have I still got news for you? Preserving trust, journalism and the public sphere
events.text: Join us for a thought-provoking conversation about the future of journalism and what Europe can do to avert the continued erosion of public trust in the digital sphere.

events.title: Europe's twin transition: creating a sustainable digital future
events.text: The defining challenge of this decade will be the twin transition towards a more sustainable and connected future. Join us for a conversation about how we can reduce the internet's hidden environmental costs and harness its transformative potential for environmental action.

events.title: Solutions or solutionism? The role of technology in times of crisis
events.text: Join us for an examination of the role that the internet and emerging technologies can play in responding to crises. What can we do to better prepare ourselves for future systemic shocks? And how do we ensure that technology targets complex problems effectively, without excluding people or causing unintended harm?

events.title: Tackling the city challenge: cities for digital rights
events.text: From ensuring the fairness of AI-assisted decisionmaking to the sustainability challenge of IoT-enabled smart cities - how we design the Next Generation Internet will have a significant impact on the daily lives of city dwellers. Join the City Coalition for Digital Rights (CC4DR) for the launch of the City Challenge and an interactive look at some of the European cities that are already pursuing meaningful digital transformation by putting people and their environment first.

events.title: Who is who? The future of digital identity, trust and privacy
events.text: Questions of identity, trust and data ownership are at the core of many of the internet's oldest and most formidable challenges. But they also hold great potential to empower individuals and make the internet more human-centric. Join us for a look at the latest developments in trust and identity in Europe and beyond - from nascent use cases to the challenges still in front of us.

events.title: Towards a more inclusive internet: a call to action
events.text: In this interactive closing session, we will explore how the internet of the future can, once again, become a driver for inclusion and social empowerment - both in Europe and at a global scale.
